instruction: How were machine learning models utilized in the non-destructive assessment of E. coli ATCC 8739 contamination in Persian leek using visible/near-infrared spectroscopy?
Output: Machine learning models were utilized in the non-destructive assessment of E. coli ATCC 8739 contamination in Persian leek using visible/near-infrared spectroscopy through three variable selection approaches: Genetic Algorithm-PLSDA, interval PLS algorithm-DA, and variable influence on projection scores-PLSDA. These models were combined with partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLSDA) to create a chemometrics tool for detecting E. coli contamination. The models were trained and validated using reflectance spectra measured on different treatments of E. coli solution on leek samples. The final developed model, selected by the genetic algorithm, showed high performance with 100% sensitivity, 98% specificity, and 0.8 classification error. The models demonstrated a high prediction ability (>95% correct classification in internal validation set and >89% in external validation set) using specific spectral distances between 490, 500, 570, 740, and 970 nm and the presence of E. coli contamination. Overall, the machine learning models, combined with visible/near-infrared spectroscopy, proved to be feasible and practical for non-destructive detection of E. coli contamination in Persian leek.
